name: Moon Golf
the-point: Golf is the only sport to have ever been played on the moon.

name: Olympic Gold
the-point: Modern Olympic gold medals are actually 92.5% silver and only plated with about 6 grams of gold.

name: Marathon Origin
the-point: The marathon length (26.2 miles) was set during the 1908 Olympics so the race could finish in front of the Royal Box.

name: Baseball Stitching
the-point: Every official MLB baseball has exactly 108 double stitches.

name: Fastest Sport
the-point: Jai Alai features ball speeds up to 188 mph, making it one of the world's fastest sports.

name: Table Tennis Speed
the-point: Professional table tennis players can hit a ball with enough spin to rotate it 150 times per second.

name: The First Sport
the-point: Wrestling is considered the oldest sport in the world, with cave drawings dating back 20,000 years.

name: Boxing Longevity
the-point: Boxing was a sport in the ancient Olympic Games as early as 688 BC.

name: Basketball's Dr. James
the-point: Basketball was originally played with peach baskets, and the bottoms weren't cut out, so the ref had to fetch the ball after every score.

name: NFL Game Time
the-point: In an average three-hour NFL broadcast, the ball is actually in play for only about 11 minutes.

name: Shuttlecock Physics
the-point: A badminton shuttlecock is the fastest object in sports, with a record smash of 306 mph.

name: Michael Jordanâ€™s Retirement
the-point: Michael Jordan made more money from Nike in 2014 than he did during his entire 15-season NBA career.

name: Tennis Scoring
the-point: The term 'Love' in tennis (meaning zero) likely comes from the French word 'l'oeuf' (the egg), representing a zero shape.

name: Formula 1 Gravity
the-point: F1 drivers can experience up to 5G of lateral force while cornering, which is equivalent to five times their body weight.

name: Golf Ball Dimples
the-point: Dimples on a golf ball create turbulence that actually reduces drag, allowing the ball to fly twice as far as a smooth one.

name: Left-Handed Advantage
the-point: Left-handed athletes have a significant advantage in 'interactive' sports like fencing and boxing because opponents aren't used to the angles.

name: The Super Bowl
the-point: The Super Bowl is the second-largest day for food consumption in the U.S., after Thanksgiving.

name: Tour de France Energy
the-point: A cyclist in the Tour de France burns roughly 6,000 to 7,000 calories per day.

name: Sumo Stability
the-point: Sumo wrestlers eat a specific stew called Chankonabe to maintain a high weight while keeping significant muscle mass.

name: Reaction Time
the-point: An MLB 95-mph fastball reaches the plate in 0.4 seconds, which is faster than the human eye can blink.

name: Icelandic Fitness
the-point: Iceland has won the 'World's Strongest Man' title more times per capita than any other nation.

name: Horse Racing Heights
the-point: Thoroughbred horses are all considered to have the same 'birthday' (January 1st) for racing eligibility regardless of when they were born.

name: High Jump Shift
the-point: The 'Fosbury Flop' (jumping backward) revolutionized the high jump after Dick Fosbury won gold with it in 1968.

name: Chess as a Sport
the-point: The International Olympic Committee officially recognizes Chess as a sport.

name: Ball Life
the-point: During a typical MLB game, about 100 to 120 baseballs are used.
